metadata.title: Potential benefits and phytotoxicity of bulk and nano-chitosan on the growth, morphogenesis, physiology, and micropropagation of Capsicum annuum

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Plant Physiology and Biochemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/plaphy
Research article
Potential benefits and phytotoxicity of bulk and nano-chitosan on the growth, morphogenesis, physiology, and micropropagation of Capsicum annuum
Ghasem Asgari-Targhia, Alireza Iranbakhsha,∗, Zahra Oraghi Ardebilib
a Department of Biology, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran bDepartment of Biology, Garmsar Branch, Islamic Azad University, Garmsar, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Elicitor In vitro Nano-chitosan Nanoparticle Tissue culture Toxicity
A B S T R A C T
Concerning environmental issues of metal based-nanomaterials and increasing demand for nano-based products; various strategies have been employed to find eco-friendly natural nano-compounds, among which nanopolymer chitosan is mostly considered. Herein, the various aspects of the way in which bulk or nano-chitosan may modify growth, morphogenesis, micropropagation, and physiology of Capsicum annuum L. were considered. Culture medium was manipulated with different concentrations of bulk chitosan or synthesized chitosan/tripolyphosphate (TPP) nano-particle. The supplementations of culture media led to changes in morphology (especially, the root architecture) and differentiation. Toxic doses of bulk (100mgL−1) or nano-chitosan (5, 10, and 20mgL−1) dramatically provoked cessation of plant growth and development. Plant growth and biomass accumulations were increased along with the suitable levels of bulk or nano-chitosan. Peroxidase and catalase activities in a dose and organ-dependent manners were significantly modified by the supplements. Phenylalanine ammonia lyase was induced by the mentioned supplements. Also, the contents of soluble phenols, proline, and alkaloid were found to be significantly increased by the elicitors, over the control. The nano-chitosan of 1mgL−1 was found to be the most effective elicitor to trigger organogenesis via micropropagation. The huge differences between triggering and toxic concentrations of the supplements would be due to the physicochemical modifications of nano-polymeric. Furthermore, the results highlight the potential benefits (hormone-like activity) and phytotoxic impacts of nano-chitosan/TPP for in vitro manipulations. This is the first report on both the favorable and adverse effects of nano-chitosan/TPP, representing requirements for further investigation on such formulations for future applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Chitosan (a biopolymer component of fungal cell walls and formed by deacetylation of chitin) possess various vital characteristics making it worldwide applicable in many industries, including agriculture, food, and medicine (Pichyangkura and Chadchawan, 2015). Chitosan is known to be the second most vital natural polymer, low toxic, and inexpensive compound (Pirbalouti et al., 2017). It has been well documented that chitosan may inhibit some fungal plant pathogens in both in vitro condition and host plants. Antibacterial, antiviral, and antifungal characteristics of chitosan have been well studied. It is agriculturally applied as an elicitor to trigger plant defense system, inducing molecular medications and/or increasing plant yield (Pirbalouti et al., 2017). There are some reports indicating the various considerable effects of supplemented-chitosan on different plant species, such as
promoting plant growth (Guan et al., 2009), enhancing production of secondary metabolites (Sathiyabama et al., 2016), affecting photosynthesis (Zong et al., 2017), influencing activities of different critical enzymes (Lin et al., 2005), and improving plant resistance against abiotic stress condition (Guan et al., 2009). There are various mechanisms triggered by chitosan, such as affecting protein phosphorylation (Felix et al., 1993), generating reactive oxygen species (Kuchitsu et al., 1995), biosynthesis of jasmonic acid as a critical hormone-like substance (Nojiri et al., 1996), and the expression of defenseresponsive genes (Minami et al., 1996). There is evidence that chitosan has an effective potency to induce various defense mechanisms in plants against abiotic stress conditions, like salinity (Zou et al., 2015). The nano-chitosan improved protection of fingermillet (Eleusine coracana Gaertn) plants against Pyricularia grisea (Sathiyabama and Manikandan, 2016). However, there are limited research studies on

Nanotechnology is regarded as one of the extensively developing technologies and novel applications of various nano-materials in agriculture and food industry are rapidly growing. Alterations in the seed germination process, plant growth, nutrient utilization, the production of vital secondary metabolites, and plant resistance to different abiotic and biotic stress are the main purposes of the supplementation of nanocompounds (Javed et al., 2017). Nanoparticles possess an efficient potency to impacts various cellular physiology and biochemistry in plants (Javed et al., 2017). However, there are some rapidly increasing reports on toxicity of various nano-compounds, mainly dependent on the type, concentration, size, and method of application. Nano-particles have many potential benefits in agriculture in order to develop techniques and strategies due to their unique physicochemical characteristics, thereby improving plant productivity and protection. For instance, nanotechnology aims to develop pesticide delivery, thereby reducing the uncontrolled usage of conventional pesticides and ensuring their safe consumptions (Nuruzzaman et al., 2016). However, the applications of various metal-based nanoparticles, most widely applied in agriculture, are doubtful, mainly because of concerns about their possible environmental toxicity. Therefore, various strategies for improving crop protection have been employed to find the naturalbased eco-friendly nano-compounds owing advantages, including biocompatibility, biodegradability, and ecological safety (Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016). Among those natural substances, chitosan (a biocompatible and biodegradable polymer having an enormous potential of structural modifications) is a preferably suitable candidate for sustainable agriculture (Shukla et al., 2013; Kashyap et al., 2015). It is obvious that more precise studies are required to clarify the possible phytotoxicity of these polymeric nano-compounds.
Plant culture in in vitro condition provides a suitable way to elucidate mechanisms implicated in plant responses to various supplemented compounds.
Capsicum annuum L., a species of the plant genus Capsicum, belongs to the Solanaceae, an important family regarding the presence of critical plants producing vital alkaloids (Iranbakhsh et al., 2006; Safari et al., 2017). There are limited research studies on the in vitro applications of nano-chitosan on the various aspects of plant growth, development, and physiology. The present study describes the synthesis of chitosan/tripolyphosphate (TPP) nano-particle and evaluates its possible effects on the plant growth, differentiation, morphogenesis, physiology, and micropropagation to identify potential benefits and phytotoxicity. Herein, the different aspects of the way in which bulk or nano-chitosan may affect the growth, differentiation, morphogenesis, physiology, and micropropagation of Capsicum annuum Var. PP805 Godiva, was considered in in vitro conditions to provide valuable comparative data and clarify key factors and mechanisms implicated in eliciting or toxicity phenomenon in these kinds of plant-interactions, for the first time on the basis of our best knowledge.

sections.heading: 2.1. Plant materials
sections.text: Seeds of Capsicum annuum PP805 Godiva were purchased from a reliable industrial center (Pop Vriend Seeds, Netherlands).

sections.heading: 2.2. Nano-chitosan synthesis and characteristics
sections.text:
The characteristics of the applied bulk chitosan were low molecular weight (110 kDa) and de-acetylation degree of 85%–90%, made by Solarbio Life Sciences Company.
Chitosan nanoparticles were synthesized by ionic cross-linking of
chitosan with TPP according to the method of Anitha et al. (2009) with some experimental modifications. Briefly, bulk chitosan of 0.1% (w/v) in 1% (v/v) aqueous acetic acid solution was prepared, stirred for 1 h, and pH was adjusted on five using sodium hydroxide (finally, the solution was filtered by Millipore of 0.45 μm). The nanoparticles were spontaneously synthesized by slowly adding 1mL of filtered TPP of 1% (pH: 4, adjusted by acetic acid of 20% (v/v)), to a 10mL of chitosan solution, under constant stirring at room temperature for 30min. Then, the solution was placed for one hour at ambient temperature to form nano-chitosan gel. The obtained gel was centrifuged (Hettich Centrifuge MIKRO 22 R) and the supernatant was discarded (this process was repeated at least for three times until achieving an appropriate pH). Then, the resulting sediment containing nanoparticles was purified, dispersed in deionized water, and finally lyophilized by freezing drying method (CHRiST ALPHA model 1–4 LD plus). The characteristics of the synthesized nano-chitosan, including UV-Vis spectrophotometric method, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Dynamic light scattering (DLS) analysis, and recording Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM) image were done after the lyophilization process except for X-ray diffraction (XRD). The UV-Vis spectrophotometric method was applied to record spectrum of each compound (bulk or nano-chitosan/TPP). DLS was used for measuring an average particle size and polydispersity index (PDI) of nanoparticles using high performance particle zetasizer (Malvern, UK). Zeta potential of the nanoparticle was measured using Zetasizer (Malvern, UK). The size and morphology of the chitosan nanoparticle were evaluated by FESEM (MIRA3, TESCAN).

sections.heading: 2.3. Treatments and growth conditions
sections.text:
Seeds were surface-sterilized with 3% sodium hypochlorite, containing two drops liquid detergent for ten min. Then, seeds were thoroughly washed three times with sterile distilled water. Murashige and Skoog (MS) medium (Murashige and Skoog, 1962; purchased from PhytoTechnology Laboratories, USA) was applied for the experiments. The applied concentrations were selected based on the pre-test findings, ranging from different beneficial to severe toxic levels of bulk or nanochitosan. The sterilized seeds were cultured in hormone-free MS medium supplemented with different concentrations of bulk chitosan (0, 1, 10, 20, and 100mgL−1) or nano-chitosan (0, 1, 5, 10, and 20mgL−1). All cultures were incubated in a germinator at 25 °C under illumination of 39.6 μmol photon m−2 s−1 (16 h of light and 8 h of dark). The treatment groups were called as follows:
Control; Bulk chitosan of 1mgL−1- BC1; Bulk chitosan of 10mgL−1BC10; Bulk chitosan of 20mgL−1- BC20; Bulk chitosan of 100mgL−1BC100; nano-chitosan of 1mgL−1- nC1; nano-chitosan of 5mgL−1nC5; nano-chitosan of 10mgL−1- nC10; nano-chitosan of 20mgL−1nC20.

sections.heading: 2.4. Determination of growth-related characteristics
sections.text: Various growth-related characteristics, including total dry mass of seedlings, total leaf area, root length, total root fresh mass, total leaf fresh weight were measured for all the treatments. However, the other physiological traits were measured only for non-toxic treatments, including Control, BC1, BC10, BC20, and nC1.

sections.heading: 2.5. Enzyme extraction
sections.text: Enzymes were extracted from leaves and roots (respectively, 0.2 and 0.3 g fresh weight of powdered organs in liquid nitrogen) at 4 °C using 1mL of extraction buffer (0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH of 7.5), containing 0.5mM Na2-EDTA and 0.5mM ascorbic acid). The prepared homogenates were centrifuged at 4 °C and the supernatants were applied as an enzyme extract.

sections.heading: 2.6. Peroxidase and catalase activities
sections.text: Peroxidase (EC 1.11.1.x) activity was measured according to the previously method described by Hemeda and Klein (1990). Catalase (EC 1.11.1.6) activity was determined based on method represented by Dhindsa et al. (1981).

sections.heading: 2.7. Determination of phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL) activity
sections.text: PAL (EC 4.3.1.5) activity was measured according to the method previously represented by Beaudoin-Eagan and Thorpe (1985). The enzyme activity was calculated by assessing the amount of produced cinnamate compound using the standard curve of cinnamic acid and expressed in micromole cinnamate per minute per gram fresh weight (μgCin min−1g−1fw).

sections.heading: 2.8. Measurement of proline content
sections.text: Proline content was carried out based on the method presented by Bates et al. (1973). Proline was extracted using sulfa salicylic acid (3% w/v). The mixtures of extract, glacial acetic acid and ninhydrin reagent were kept at boiling water bath for one hour. After cooling, vigorously mixing with toluene, this phase was used for measuring absorbance at 520 nm. Proline contents were determined, mainly based on the proline standard curve and finally expressed in milligrams per gram leaf fresh weigh (mgg−1fw).

sections.heading: 2.9. Determination of total soluble phenols
sections.text: The soluble phenols were extracted using ethanol solvent of 80% (v/ v) and holding in boiling water bath for 20min. Folin Ciocalteu method was applied. Content of total soluble phenols were calculated based on the standard curve of tannic acid as a standard and finally, expressed in milligrams per gram leaf fresh weigh (mgg−1fw).

sections.heading: 2.10. Alkaloid determination
sections.text: Alkaloid contents were measured according to the procedure presented by Harborne (1973). Briefly, leaves were homogenized with 10mL of 10% (v/v) acetic acid in ethanol and allowed to stand for at least 4 h. Then, it was filtered and the prepared extract was concentrated on a water bath. The concentrated ammonium hydroxide was added drop wise to the extract until the precipitation process was complete. The whole solution was allowed to settle and the precipitated was collected. The residue (the alkaloid) was resolved in 0.1M H2SO4. The maximum absorbance in 270–380 nm was estimated and finally, the alkaloid content expressed in OD g− 1fw.

sections.heading: 2.11. Micropropagation experiment
sections.text: In a supplementary experiment, shoot tips of 28-day old seedlings were applied as explants and cultured in MS medium supplemented with the bulk chitosan of 0, 10mgL−1, or the nano-chitosan of 1mgL−1. All cultures were incubated in a germinator at 25 °C under illumination of 39.6 μmol photon m−2 s−1 (16 h of light and 8 h of dark). Forty five days after culture, the micro-propagated plants were harvested, photographed, and subjected to further analysis, including total fresh weight, total root fresh mass, total leaf fresh mass, and total leaf area.

sections.heading: 2.12. Statistical analysis
sections.text:
Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 16 software. All data are expressed as mean ± standard error (SE) values of three independent replicates. Significant mean differences between the treatments were done in form of one-way analysis of variance based on
Duncan's multiple range test at the level of P≤ 0.05. Differences were considered significant at the probability level of p≤ 0.05.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characteristics of nano-chitosan
sections.text:
The determination of absorption patterns of monochromatic lights is regarded as a valuable method for the recognition of complex ions (Fahim et al., 2013). The recorded differences in the UV-Vis spectra of the bulk and nano-chitosan/TPP manifested the formation of a complex between TPP and the chitosan in the nanoparticle (Fig. 1A.1 and A.2). The peak at the region of 250–350 nm refers to electronic transition involving the lone pair of electrons on the phosphate group and TPP oxygen atom (Fahim et al., 2013; Abdel-Wahhab et al., 2015). This result confirms the interaction between anionic phosphate of TPP and cationic amino groups of chitosan (Abdel-Wahhab et al., 2015). Surface charge and thereby stability of the synthesized nanoparticle was estimated based on the zeta potential value. The zeta potential of the prepared nano-chitosan/TPP was +60.4 ± 4.6 mV, indicating positive surface charges (Fig. 1B). This finding is consistent with the obtained results by Anitha et al. (2009). The obtained zeta potential value confirms that the synthesized nanoparticle is stable. Size and zeta potential as important key physicochemical characteristics of nanoparticles control the interactions of these compounds with plants, hence affecting the physiological responses in exposed plants (Nakasato et al., 2017). The zeta potentials of the synthesized nanoparticle were positive (because of the residual protonated amine groups), indicative of good colloidal stability, mainly due to the electrostatic excretion between the nanoparticles, hence avoiding aggregation phenomenon. The size distribution by the intensity in aqueous solution based on the DLS analysis (represented in Fig. 1C) shows the hydrodynamic radius of the prepared polymeric nano-chitosan, 163 nm, and Z-average (r.nm) amount is 241.1. Nano-chitosan/TPP showed 0.416 PDI. The recorded sharp peak and low amount of PDI indicate that the nanoparticle has narrow size distribution (Fig. 1C). The obtained value of PDI for the synthesized nanoparticle is in agreement with findings of Nakasato et al. (2017).
The morphology and average size estimated using FE-SEM. The synthesized polymer nano-chitosan has spherical morphology (Fig. 1D). The estimated mean size of the nano-chitosan using FESEM was 43.32 (r.nm), much smaller than the value obtained using DLS analysis (Fig. 1D). The recorded size difference between FESEM and DLS analyses may be attributed to different principle contributed to these techniques (Papadimitriou et al., 2008; Gokce et al., 2014; Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016). The mismatch of the achieved results by DLS and FESEM is a normal and common issue. In FESEM image, the particles are precisely measurable, while the dynamic radius is measured and separating each of the particles is not possible in the DLS analysis (the limitation of this technique). In agreement with our finding, the size of the nano-chitosan estimated based on the TEM micrographs (50–70 nm) was much smaller than the size determined by DLS (350 nm), mainly for swelling of chitosan in contact with water (Papadimitriou et al., 2008). It is obvious that the precise size is determined based on TEM or FESEM image (not DLS). Regarding nanochitosan, the smallest size and narrowest size distributions are achieved, when nanoparticles were not freeze-dried. However, for longterm storage, freeze-drying, utilization of cryo-protectants, and ultrasonication have been recommended (Gokce et al., 2014). Therefore, the prepared nanoparticle in this study represented ideal characteristics in terms of size, PDI, and zeta potential.
FTIR spectra of bulk and nano-chitosan clearly confirmed the chemical modification of the nano-particle. In FTIR spectra (Fig. 2A) the presence of bands around 3400 cm−1 refers to the overlap of O-H and N-H stretching (Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016), where a shift from 3376 to 3443 cm−1 was found in the prepared nano-particle. The peaks recorded between 2850 cm−1 and 2950 cm−1 refer to the presence of methyl, where the peak of 2873 in the bulk chitosan shifts to a shoulder at about 2950 in its nano-form. The recorded peaks at
1644 cm−1 (C-O stretching) and 1542 cm−1 (NH2 asymmetric stretching) show the cross-link of the ammonium group of chitosan to the poly-phosphoric of TPP (Xu and Du, 2003; Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016). This modifies inter and intra-molecular interactions in the chitosan nanoparticle (Knaul et al., 1999; Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016). The bulk chitosan FTIR spectrum reflects the presence of characteristic peaks of amide (1602 cm−1) and amino (1156 cm−1) groups (Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016). The observed bands around 1385 cm−1, 1080 and 890 cm-1 refer to C-H bending, C-N stretching, and C-H bending, respectively (Manikandan and Sathiyabama, 2016). The alteration in stretching frequency in the chitosan/TPP complex compound may be attributed to the TPP interaction with ammonium group of the chitosan and more hydrogen bonding (Anitha et al., 2009). XRD analysis confirms the nano-chitosan presence (Fig. 2B). The peaks ranging from 30 to 40 theta scales represent the crystalline nature of the prepared nanoparticle (Fig. 2B).

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphogenesis and growth-related characteristics
sections.text:
The supplementations of culture media with the bulk or nanochitosan led to the considerable changes in morphology (especially root architecture) and cellular differentiation of the exposed seedlings, over the untreated control (Fig. 3 A–N). The bulk chitosan of 100mgL−1 and nano-chitosan of 5, 10, and 20mgL−1 had dramatic growth-inhibiting impacts and provoked an extreme cessation of the root development. Considering the growth promoting and toxic concentrations, there was a massive difference between the nano-chitosan and its bulk form, where the effectiveness of the nano-type was much higher than the bulk at the same levels. When the bulk chitosan at the levels of 10 or 20mgL−1 was applied, the root lengths were decreased significantly (p≤ 0.05) by 34% and 18.5%, respectively compared to the control
(Fig. 4A). This characteristic was increased about 10% for the nC1 treatment group, over the control (Fig. 4A). The dramatic and significant (p≤ 0.05) interruption in the root development was recorded in the BC100 (95%), nC5 (69%), nC10 (76%), and nC20 (84%) treatment groups, relative to the control seedlings grown in chitosan-free MS medium (Fig. 4A). It is interesting to note that, a significant (p≤ 0.05) increase in the total root fresh mass was observed by 77%, two folds, and 44.5% for nC1, BC10, and BC20, respectively over the control (Fig. 4B). However, the bulk chitosan of 100mgL−1 and the nanochitosan of 5, 10, and 20mgL−1 had the significant reducing impacts on the root fresh weight about 94%, 70%, 82%, and 93%, respectively compared to the control samples (Fig. 4B). In comparison to the control, total leaf area were increased by 52%, 34%, and 23% for the nC1, BC10, and BC20 treatments (respectively), while these parameters were decreased dramatically by 95%, 79%, 88%, and 91% for the BC100, nC5, nC10, and nC20 treatment groups (Fig. 4C). It is interesting to note that the highest amounts of total leaf fresh weights were recorded in the BC10, nC1, and BC20 which were significantly higher than the control group by 35%, 28%, and 16.8%, respectively (Fig. 4D). The supplementations of culture media with bulk or nano-chitosan led to significant (p≤ 0.05) increases in total dry mass for nC1 (41%), BC10 (58%), and BC20 (25%) treatments and decreases for BC100 (89%), nC5 (69%), nC10 (86%), and nC20 (88%), over control seedlings grown in chitosan free medium (Fig. 4E). The promotions in the growth traits and biomass accumulation provoked by the nano-chitosan of 1mgL−1 were nearly similar to the responses triggered by 10 and 20mgL−1 of
the bulk form. However, its higher concentrations (5, 10, and 20mgL−1) inhibited the growth indexes, resembling the responses found for the bulk type at levels of 100mgL−1.

sections.heading: 3.3. Peroxidase and catalase
sections.text: In comparison with the control, a significant enhancement in the leaf catalase activity was observed in BC10 (25.5%), and nC1 (33%), while this parameter declined by 21.5% for BC20 (Fig. 5A). It is interesting to note that catalase activities in root were significantly decreased by 26.5%, 70.8%, and 82%, respectively, for BC10, BC20, and nC1, respectively over the untreated control (Fig. 5B). Except for BC1, peroxidase activities in leaves of the supplemented seedlings significantly increased by 63%, 23%, and 48.77%, respectively, for BC10, BC20, and nC1 compared to the control (Fig. 5C). The significant inductions in the root peroxidase activities were recorded in BC10 (30%), while the dramatic decreases were found in BC20 (48%) and nC1 (53%), over the control (Fig. 5D).

sections.heading: 3.4. PAL, proline, soluble phenols, and alkaloid
sections.text:
The significant and dramatic inductions in leaf PAL activities by 52%, 27%, and 61%, respectively were recorded for BC10, BC20, and nC1, compared with the control (Fig. 6A). Significant enhances in total soluble phenols were recorded in the bulk or nano-chitosan- treated seedlings among which the highest amounts were found in nC1 group,
about 25% over the control (Fig. 6B). The proline contents were found to be significantly (p≤ 0.05) increased by 17%, 23.7%, and 22% for BC10, BC20, and nC1 treatments, respectively over the untreated
control (Fig. 6C). Supplementation of the culture medium with the bulk or nano chitosan led to slight and significant increases in total alkaloid contents by 17%, 14%, and 19% for BC10, BC20, and nC1, respectively
compared to the control (Fig. 6D).

sections.heading: 3.5. Organogenesis via micropropagation
sections.text: The organogenesis behavior of the applied explant during the micropropagation was modified by MS supplementations with bulk chitosan of 10mgL−1 or nano-chitosan of 1mgL−1 (Fig. 7). The nanochitosan at the level of 1mgL−1 was found to be the most effective treatment to trigger the organogenesis process (Fig. 7). The supplementation of culture medium with the bulk or nano-chitosan led to the significant and dramatic increases in the total fresh mass (Fig. 8A) by 41% and 79%, the root fresh weight (Fig. 8B) by 69% and 2.5 fold, the total leaf fresh mass (Fig. 8C) by 34% and 87%, as well as the total leaf area (Fig. 8D) by 54% and 2 fold, respectively, for BC10 and nC1 treatment groups in comparison with the control.

sections.heading: 4.1. Morphology, growth, and differentiation
sections.text:
Manipulation of culture media by different kinds of elicitors in in vitro condition is considered as one of the most effective methods to influence a cellular differentiation process and trigger cellular secondary metabolism. The results indicated that the chitosan form and the applied concentrations are the key parameters on the effectiveness of these elicitors. The synthesized nano-chitosan in the current research represented the ideal characteristics in terms of size, PDI, zeta potential, and chemical modification, thereby controlling its interactions with plant cellular components and altering the physiological responses in the exposed seedlings. The findings showed that the toxic concentrations of the nano-chitosan/TPP are extremely lower than the bulk form. Therefore, it may be concluded that nano-chitosan of 1mgL−1 (equal to 10 and 20mgL−1 of the bulk form) exert a plant growth promoting
effect, whereas its higher concentrations (5, 10, and 20mgL−1) represent a dramatic growth cessation (similar to the responses found for the bulk type at 100mgL−1). The physicochemical modification of nano-chitosan and possibly different interactions and induced mechanisms may contribute to the observed huge differences between plant reactions to the applied doses of the bulk and nano-chitosan/TPP
and it seems that it is not quite related to the size characterization. Cu–chitosan nanoparticles exhibited higher antifungal capabilities than the bulk form against Alternaria solani and Fusarium oxysporum (Saharan et al., 2015). Nanoparticles of Cu-chitosan improved maize seedling growth via up-regulating the enzymes involved in mobilization of storages, reflecting the potential benefits of utilization of other micronutrients in the form of metal-chitosan based nano-compounds, taking into account sustainable agriculture (Saharan et al., 2016). Chromatin condensation, destruction of the nuclei, DNA fragmentation, cytoplasmic shrinkage, and activation of caspase 3-like protease have been mentioned as the key mechanisms implicated in the chitosan-induced programmed-cell death pathway (Zuppini et al., 2004; Vasil'ev et al., 2009). Recently, it has been hypothesized that chitosan and its nanoderivatives have antimicrobial effects and affect plant growth and defense system through multiple lines of actions, including cell wall disruption, membrane depolarization, inductions of the expression of various genes, inhibition electron transport, chromatin alterations, protein denaturation, inductions in defense system, production of pathogenesis-related (PR) proteins, synthesis of defense-responsive hormones (jasmonic acid, salicylic acid, and abscisic acid), increases in cytosolic Ca2+ ion as a key secondary messenger, and activation of MAP-kinases (Choudhary et al., 2017). Therefore, regarding to the recorded extreme differences in the promoting and toxic concentrations of bulk and nano-chitosan, it may be concluded that the modified physicochemical characteristics in combination with more efficient inter and intra-cellular interactions of nano-form compared to the bulk, especially at the levels of cell wall, membranes, DNA, proteins, and/or hormones as well as their following signaling are responsible for the observed findings. However, this is the first report on the plant interaction with nano-polymeric chitosan in in vitro, on the basis of our best knowledge. It is interesting to note that recently, the chitosan/TPP nano-particles severely inhibited germination due to its physicochemical characteristics, and negatively affected the initial growth of Zea mays, Brassica rapa, and Pisum sativum (Nakasato et al., 2017). The obtained results clearly showed that chitosan in form of the bulk or nano has an effective potency to influence root architecture, mainly in a dose-dependent manner. It should be emphasized that the toxic levels of
the nano-chitosan were much lower than the bulk type and led to the extreme cessation of root development. It seems that root meristem is more sensitive than shoot to bulk or nano-chitosan. It is interesting to note that in maize seedlings, the most dramatic impact of the inhibiting concentration (0.16%) of Cu-chitosan nanoparticle was on root characteristics (number and length) (Saharan et al., 2016). This is the first report on the phytotoxicity of this nano-particle, in in vitro condition and the exact involved mechanisms are unknown. It is possible that affecting the root meristem, cellular polarity, and/or cyclin-dependent kinases are responsible for the interruption of root development. It seems that the bulk or nano-chitosan in a dose-dependent manner may act as an external signal to elicit complex alterations in root cellular differentiation, growth and development (especially lateral roots), probably via provoking changes in source/sink relations and/or hormonal balances, especially auxin (a rhizogen hormone), as well as their hormone-like activities. There is evidence that chitosan may modify the growth and development processes by affecting some signaling pathway related to auxin biosynthesis (Uthairatanakij et al., 2007). It is obvious that more convincing studies are required to clarify the exact involved mechanisms. In agreement with our findings, Sopalun et al. (2010) reported that high levels of chitosan (100mgL−1) may suppress growth rate and kill protocorm-like bodies. Therefore, the obtained data clearly depict that the potential benefits and toxic doses of the bulk chitosan are extremely different from the nano-chitosan/TPP, mainly due to their physicochemical differences and interactions with cellular components.

sections.heading: 4.2. Antioxidant enzymes
sections.text:
The above-described changes in the antioxidant enzymes; peroxidase and catalase as the main parts of defense system showed that the enzyme activities in the exposed roots were more affected than the leaves. The nano-chitosan/TPP influenced antioxidant enzymes in the much lower concentration, compared with the bulk chitosan. The nanochitosan-modified activities of these antioxidant enzymes at low concentrations may suggest that redox status is extremely affected. The chitosan is known as an elicitor to trigger the defense system in plants.
The observed dramatic declining effects of the applied supplements on the catalase and peroxidase activities in the root tissues may probably lead to the accumulation of H2O2, thereby triggering signal transduction, modifying the expression of defense-responsive genes, influencing the enzyme activities, enhancing the production of secondary metabolites, and triggering programmed cell death, mainly at the high doses which is not examined in the current study. The recorded changes in the antioxidant enzymes may be attributed to the increases in salicylic acid and/or nitric oxide contents and the following signaling. Chitosan has a potency to induce the accumulations of H2O2, thereby triggering defense responses (Lin et al., 2005; Choudhary et al., 2017). Nano-chitosan supplementation induced the peroxidase and accumulation of reactive oxygen species in tea (Chandra et al., 2015), fingermillet (Sathiyabama and Manikandan, 2016), turmeric plants (Anusuya and Sathiyabama, 2016), cowpea (Berger et al., 2016), and Brassica rapa (Zong et al., 2017). There is evidence that chitosan-triggered accumulations of nitric oxide and its following signaling are involved in eliciting the chitosan-triggered defense responses (Chandra et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 4.3. PAL, soluble phenols, proline and alkaloid
sections.text: The recorded alterations in the PAL activity and the accumulations of proline, soluble phenols and alkaloid contents provoked by the applied supplements, clearly indicated that the nano-chitosan may act as a more effective elicitor than the bulk. The potential benefits of the chitosan as an elicitor for improving production of secondary metabolites is well documented. However, there is no report on the potential benefits and phytotoxicity of the nano-polymeric chitosan in in vitro condition. Chitosan application in cell culture of Scrophularia striata improved accumulation of aromatic amino acids via up-regulating of the PAL gene (Kamalipourazad et al., 2016). The application of chitosan as an elicitor led to the biosynthesis of secondary metabolites, such as phenolics in Vitis vinifera (Cai et al., 2012), curcumin in turmeric plants (Anusuya and Sathiyabama, 2016), the hydrolysable tannin in Phyllanthus debilis (Malayaman et al., 2017), and essential oil in Eucalyptus citriodora (Ali et al., 2014), Mentha piperita (Ahmad et al., 2017), and Thymus daenensis (Bistgani et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 4.4. Micro-propagation
sections.text: The recorded modifications in the organogenesis process via micropropagation clearly confirmed the hormone-like activities of the bulk or nano chitosan, especially the latter. The nano-chitosan/TPP represented much higher hormone-like activity than the bulk form at the much lower concentration which could be attributed to the exclusive physicochemical modified structure of the nanoparticle. Findings of Sopalun et al. (2010) on the effects of the chitosan on micropropagation of Grammatophyllum speciosum revealed that this biopolymer may act as a plant growth stimulator for tissue culture. Chitosan has an effective potency to induce the considerable morphological and structural changes as well as molecular disorganization of the fungal cells (Berger et al., 2016). Chitosan biopolymer may apply as a plant growth stimulator in in vitro condition (Nge et al., 2006). Therefore, the synthesized nano-polymeric chitosan/TPP in the current study has an efficient potency to act as an elicitor and represents an outstanding hormone-like activity at low concentrations. Thus, manipulating of culture medium with chitosan nanoparticle may be exploited for delivery of an alternative approach for the micro-propagation and may also decrease contamination rate.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The various aspects of the way in which bulk or nano-chitosan/TPP may modify growth, differentiation, morphogenesis, micropropagation, and physiology of Capsicum annuum, were considered in in vitro conditions. This research depicts the comparative remarkable data about
the potential benefits and phytotoxic impacts of the bulk chitosan and nano-polymeric chitosan/TPP for manipulating a culture medium. The findings demonstrated that the bulk or nano-chitosan has the high effective potency to modify the architecture of organs and trigger crucial physiological traits, thereby affecting plant growth, differentiation, and metabolism. Also, the results clearly indicated that the manipulations of culture media with the bulk or nano-chitosan (especially the later) may amplify organogenesis during micro-propagation, representing the hormone-like activity. Thus, it may be employed for developing of an alternative method, taking into account the micropropagation and contamination rate. It is obvious that further studies are required to clarify the key implicated mechanisms, especially at molecular levels.

metadata.abstractText: Concerning environmental issues of metal based-nanomaterials and increasing demand for nano-based products; various strategies have been employed to find eco-friendly natural nano-compounds, among which nanopolymer chitosan is mostly considered. Herein, the various aspects of the way in which bulk or nano-chitosan may modify growth, morphogenesis, micropropagation, and physiology of Capsicum annuum L. were considered. Culture medium was manipulated with different concentrations of bulk chitosan or synthesized chitosan/tripolyphosphate (TPP) nano-particle. The supplementations of culture media led to changes in morphology (especially, the root architecture) and differentiation. Toxic doses of bulk (100mgL) or nano-chitosan (5, 10, and 20mgL) dramatically provoked cessation of plant growth and development. Plant growth and biomass accumulations were increased along with the suitable levels of bulk or nano-chitosan. Peroxidase and catalase activities in a dose and organ-dependent manners were significantly modified by the supplements. Phenylalanine ammonia lyase was induced by the mentioned supplements. Also, the contents of soluble phenols, proline, and alkaloid were found to be significantly increased by the elicitors, over the control. The nano-chitosan of 1mgL was found to be the most effective elicitor to trigger organogenesis via micropropagation. The huge differences between triggering and toxic concentrations of the supplements would be due to the physicochemical modifications of nano-polymeric. Furthermore, the results highlight the potential benefits (hormone-like activity) and phytotoxic impacts of nano-chitosan/TPP for in vitro manipulations. This is the first report on both the favorable and adverse effects of nano-chitosan/TPP, representing requirements for further investigation on such formulations for future applications.
